title: Understanding Scientific Notation
text: Scientific notation is a way of expressing very large or very small numbers. It has a format of a number between $$1$$ and $$10$$ multiplied by a power of $$10$$.

title: Simplifying the Notation
text: Observe the number $$8.16$$ in scientific notation. It's $$8.16$$ times $$10$$ raised to the power of $$11$$. The exponent on the $$10$$ indicates how many places you need to move the decimal point.

title: Handling Exponents
text: For large numbers, a positive exponent means moving the decimal point to the right. Here, you need to move the decimal $$11$$ places to the right.

title: Converting the Coefficient
text: Convert the coefficient $$8.16$$ to introduce eleven zeros after the decimal point.

title: Adjusting for Negative Numbers
text: Don't forget to keep the sign of the number when converting. Because the original number is negative, the final result should also be negative.

title: Finalizing the Conversion
text: Combine what you've learned about the decimal placement and the sign of the number to write the full standard form.
